home.info-title: Classification and Regression Models with Random Forest

intro.text: Random Forest is a machine learning algorithm that combines multiple decision trees to improve the accuracy and robustness of classification and regression models.

classifier.subtitle-1: The Random Forest classification algorithm works as follows:
classifier.text-1-1: A set of decision trees is created, each with a random sample of features and observations.
classifier.text-1-2: Each decision tree is trained with a part of the dataset and used to predict the class of the observations.
classifier.text-1-3: The predictions of each tree are combined to obtain a final prediction.
classifier.text-2-1: Robustness: Random Forest is resistant to overfitting and can handle large datasets.
classifier.text-2-2: Flexibility: It can handle different types of features, including numerical and categorical.
classifier.text-2-3: Interpretability: Individual decision trees can be interpreted to understand the relationships between features and the target class.
classifier.text-3-1: Computationally expensive: Training a Random Forest model can be slow for large datasets.
classifier.text-3-2: Sensitivity to hyperparameter selection: The choice of hyperparameters, such as the number of trees and maximum depth, can affect the accuracy of the model.

regressor.subtitle-1: The Random Forest regression algorithm works as follows:
regressor.text-1-1: A set of decision trees is created, each with a random sample of features and observations.
regressor.text-1-2: Each decision tree is trained with a part of the dataset and used to predict the continuous value.
regressor.text-1-3: The predictions of each tree are combined to obtain a final prediction.
regressor.text-2-1: Robustness: Random Forest is resistant to overfitting and can handle large datasets.
regressor.text-2-2: Flexibility: It can handle different types of features, including numerical and categorical.
regressor.text-2-3: Interpretability: Individual decision trees can be interpreted to understand the relationships between features and the target variable.
regressor.text-3-1: Computationally expensive: Training a Random Forest model can be slow for large datasets.
regressor.text-3-2: Sensitivity to hyperparameter selection: The choice of hyperparameters, such as the number of trees and maximum depth, can affect the accuracy of the model.

example.text-1: Image classification: Random Forest can be used to classify images into different categories, such as objects, people, or places.
example.text-2: House price prediction: Using features such as number of rooms, surface area, location, etc. to predict the price of a house.
example.text-3: Product demand prediction: Using features such as season, day of the week, holidays, etc. to predict the demand for a product.
example.text-4: Sports outcome prediction: Using features such as team statistics, injuries, weather conditions, etc. to predict the outcome of a game.

conclusion.text-1: In summary, Random Forest classification and regression models are powerful tools for analyzing and predicting outcomes in a variety of fields. Their ability to handle large datasets and robustness to overfitting make them ideal for real-world applications.

tooltip.text-1: Confusion Matrix: Evaluates the model's accuracy in classifying examples.

parameters.title: Obtained Parameters
parameters.precision-tooltip: Proportion of true positives among all predicted positives. (Higher is Better)
parameters.sensibility-tooltip: Proportion of correct predictions among all real values of the class. (Higher is Better)
parameters.fp-tooltip: Proportion of incorrect predictions among all real values of other classes. (Lower is Better)
parameters.f1-tooltip: Harmonic mean of precision and sensitivity. (Higher is Better)

tooltip.text-1: ROC Curve: Shows the relationship between the True Positive Rate (
tooltip.text-6: * The area under the curve (AUC) is a metric that summarizes the model's behavior. An AUC close to 1 indicates a model that can perfectly distinguish between positives and negatives, while an AUC close to 0.5 indicates a model that is no better than a random choice.

tooltip.text-1: Evaluates the model's accuracy in regression results, so a better model is represented by points closer to the central dashed line.
tooltip.text-2: The points closer to the line, the better the model is.
tooltip.text-3: The dashed line represents the real values.
tooltip.text-4: The line represents the real values.
tooltip.text-5: The closer the points are to the line, the better the model is.

tooltip.text-1: Evaluates the model's accuracy in regression results, so a better model is represented by points closer to the central dashed line.
tooltip.text-2: The points closer to the line, the better the model is.
tooltip.text-3: The dashed line represents the prediction.
tooltip.text-5: The closer the points are to the line, the better the model is.

parameters.mse-tooltip: The MSE measures the average of the squared errors between the real values and the predicted values. A low MSE indicates that the model fits the data well.
parameters.rmse-tooltip: The RMSE is the square root of the MSE. It is a metric that is easier to interpret than the MSE, since it has the same unit as the real values.
parameters.mae-tooltip: The MAE measures the average of the absolute errors between the real values and the predicted values. A low MAE indicates that the model fits the data well.
parameters.mape-tooltip: The MAPE measures the average of the absolute percentage errors between the real values and the predicted values. A low MAPE indicates that the model fits the data well.
parameters.r2-tooltip: The R² measures the proportion of the variance in the real values that is explained by the model. A high R² indicates that the model fits the data well.

tooltip.text-1: Surrogate Tree: A decision tree that is trained with the predictions of the original Random Forest model, allowing to simplify the forest to interpret the model's output in a more easy and understandable way.
